message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of non-tender, raised, inflamed, white-silver maculopapular lesions on elbows and forearms suggests the diagnosis of psoriasis. Psoriasis is characterized by basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization. Option A describes histopathologic findings in pemphigus vulgaris, option B describes findings in bullous pemphigoid, and option D describes findings in squamous cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest the diagnosis of psoriasis, and the most likely histopathologic findings in psoriasis are basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization. Option (B) describes findings in pemphigus vulgaris, (D) describes findings in squamous cell carcinoma, and (A) describes findings in pemphigus foliaceus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesions suggests psoriasis, which has the histopathologic findings of basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization. The other options are not consistent with the presentation of psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has psoriasis, which is characterized by white-silver maculopapular lesions. The histopathologic findings for psoriasis include basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and increased keratinization.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin lesions and the other symptoms suggest the patient has psoriasis, which is characterized by basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization. Intracellular edema with detachment at basal level is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, while subepidermal blister (detachment at suprabasal level) is seen in bullous pemphigoid. Nuclear atypia and cellular pleomorphism are seen in malignant tumors or dysplasia, not in psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lesions and the accompanying symptoms suggest a diagnosis of psoriasis, which is characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes, dilation of subepidermal blood vessels, and inflammation. Therefore, the most likely histopathologic finding would be basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization (option C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-tender, raised, inflamed, white-silver maculopapular lesions suggest that the patient has psoriasis. Histopathology findings in psoriasis will show basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization. Option A describes pemphigus vulgaris, option B describes bullous pemphigoid, and option D describes squamous cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and lesions match the characteristics of psoriasis, which is associated with histopathologic findings of basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization. This is option (C). Intracellular edema with detachment at the basal level is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, subepidermal blister is seen in bullous pemphigoid, and nuclear atypia and cellular pleomorphism are seen in squamous cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin lesions described in the patient suggest psoriasis, which is characterized by silver-white maculopapular lesions. The histopathologic findings typical of psoriasis include basal cell hyperplasia, subepidermal vascular proliferation, and abnormal keratinization. Options A, B, and D do not fit the typical histopathologic findings of psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the skin lesions suggests that the patient has psoriasis, which is characterized by raised, inflamed, scaly, white-silver maculopapular lesions. The most likely histopathologic findings in psoriasis include basal cell hyperplasia, proliferation of subepidermal vasculature, and keratinization, which are described in option (C).
